quiz.title: Git and GitHub Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are potential benefits of using a version control system (VCS)? Select all that apply.
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Intro to Version Control

answers.text: It creates a backup of your work.
It makes it easier to correct mistakes or undo changes.
It can be used to provide documentation of your project's history.
It makes it easier for multiple people to work on a project at the same time.
It removes the possibility of conflicts arising between different teammates' code.
answers.comments: Not quite. Although using a VCS can help make conflicts less likely, they may still arise.

answers.text: I don't know.
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time!

questions.question_text: When we run git add ., all files that have been created or modified since the last commit are staged and will be included in the next commit.

answers.text: True
answers.comments: Not quite. Be sure to review the .gitignore source for this question. You'll get it next time!
answers.comments_html: Not quite. Be sure to review the .gitignore source for this question. You'll get it next time!

answers.text: False

questions.question_text: Match each git command with the description that best suits it.
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Getting Code with GitHub Viewing the Git Commit History Working with Branches
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Getting Code with GitHub
  • Viewing the Git Commit History
  • Working with Branches

answers.text: git stash
answers.right: Enables you to temporarily save uncommitted changes so you can switch branches.

answers.text: git clone
answers.right: Enables you to copy a GitHub repo to your local environment.

answers.text: git remote
answers.right: Returns a nickname used to refer to the GitHub repo that's associated with a local repo.

answers.text: git diff
answers.right: Lists the differences between two versions of a project (e.g., at two different points in the project's history).

answers.text: git log
answers.right: Lists all the commits that have been made to a project.

matches.text: Enables you to temporarily save uncommitted changes so you can switch branches.
Enables you to copy a GitHub repo to your local environment.
Returns a nickname used to refer to the GitHub repo that's associated with a local repo.
Lists the differences between two versions of a project (e.g., at two different points in the project's history).
Lists all the commits that have been made to a project.

questions.question_text: What happens if you run git commit and forget to include a commit message?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Maintaining a Clean, Well-documented Commit History
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Maintaining a Clean, Well-documented Commit History

answers.text: Neither of these choices is true
Git aborts the commit
answers.comments: Not quite! Git opens a new file to allow you to enter a commit message. It only aborts the commit if you close the file without entering a commit message and saving it first.

answers.text: By default, Git opens a file in whatever text editor you normally use, allowing you to enter a commit message.
answers.comments: Not quite! Git opens a file in the default Git command line editor. In order for Git to use VS Code (or other text editor) as the Git command line editor, you need to configure that separately.

answers.text: I don't know
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time!

questions.question_text: The git diff command can be used to make which of the following comparisons? Select all that apply.
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Viewing the Git Commit History
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Viewing the Git Commit History

answers.text: Changes that have not yet been committed vs. the most recent commit.
Changes that have not yet been staged vs. the most recent commit.
Any two commits.
Any two branches.
I don't know
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time!

questions.question_text: Under normal circumstances (i.e., when HEAD is not in a detached state), HEAD refers to which of the following?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Viewing the Git Commit History
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Viewing the Git Commit History

answers.text: The most recent commit on the branch that is currently checked out.
The most recent commit on the main branch.
answers.comments: Close! HEAD refers to the most recent commit on whatever branch is currently checked out, which may or may not be the main branch.
answers.comments_html: Close! HEAD refers to the most recent commit on whatever branch is currently checked out, which may or may not be the main branch.

answers.text: I don't know
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time!

questions.question_text:
What markdown would we use to display "Instructions" as a second-level header? Fill in the blank:

____ Instructions
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Viewing the Git Commit History
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Viewing the Git Commit History

questions.question_text: The abbreviated version of the SHA can be used in place of the full SHA in any Git command.

answers.text: True
False
answers.comments: Not quite. The abbreviated SHA shown by Git in some views uniquely identifies the commit and can be used in place of the full SHA.

answers.text: A command that creates a separate set of commits from other commits to the same repository.
A command that creates a copy of the repository in your git profile
A command that combines two repositories.
A command that splits files into folders
A command that switches your work to the main branch.
I don't know
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time!

questions.question_text: Which one of the following actions creates a copy of a repository in the GitHub account of the person performing the action?
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Getting Code with GitHub

answers.text: Forking a repository
answers.comments: CORRECT!! Forking a repository creates a copy of the original repository in your account so you can make changes without affecting the original repository until you choose to submit a pull request which lets the owner know you have suggested changes that you think they should merge.
answers.comments_html: CORRECT!!  Forking a repository creates a copy of the original repository in your account so you can make changes without affecting the original repository until you choose to submit a pull request which lets the owner know you have suggested changes that you think they should merge.

answers.text: Cloning a repository
answers.comments: Not quite. Cloning a repository creates a working copy of one of your repositories so you can make changes and push them to the remote on GitHub.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. Cloning a repository creates a working copy of one of your repositories so you can make changes and push them to the remote on GitHub.

answers.text: Creating a branch
answers.comments: Not quite. Creating a branch allows anyone collaborating on the same repository to work on changes without affecting the main branch for the purpose of merging the changes later.

answers.text: Using pull to retrieve a repository
answers.comments: Not quite. Using the git pull command pulls the current state from the remote on GitHub to ensure that your local copy is up to date.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. Using the git pull command pulls the current state from the remote on GitHub to ensure that your local copy is up to date.

answers.text: Merging a branch in a repository
answers.comments: Not quite. Merging a branch. syncs the commits from a branch to the master branch.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. Merging a branch. syncs the commits from a branch to the master branch.

answers.text: I don't know
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time!

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the best description of GitHub?
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Getting Code with GitHub

answers.text: An internet hosting service for software development and version control using Git
answers.comments: CORRECT!! Github is an internet hosting service for software development and version control using Git.It offers the distributed version control and source code management functionality of Git, plus its own features.
answers.comments_html: CORRECT!! Github is an internet hosting service for software development and version control using Git. It offers the distributed version control and source code management functionality of Git, plus its own features.

answers.text: An software package for project collaboration
answers.comments: Not quite. Collaboration is a great feature of GitHub, but not its main focus or purpose.

answers.text: An online application for connecting with other users
answers.comments: Not quite. GitHub is not for connecting with other users, although it does have some functionality that allows you to connect with others.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. GitHub is not for connecting with other users, although it does have some functionality that allows you to connect with others.

answers.text: I don't know
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source(s) for this question. You'll get it next time!

questions.question_text: Why would you fork a repository before cloning?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Getting Code with GitHub Collaborating with Git and GitHub
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • Getting Code with GitHub
  • Collaborating with Git and GitHub

answers.text: So that you can collaborate with the repository's owner
answers.comments: CORRECT!! When you create a fork in a repository, you are creating your own branch in the repository so that you can work with the repository locally to make changes to the contents of the repository and submit a pull request for the owner to review your suggested changes.

answers.text: So that you can pull changes down
answers.comments: Creating the fork and cloning it pulls the current state of the repository at that point, but any future changes will need to be pulled manually.

answers.text: So that you can publish any changes you make
answers.comments: You can publish changes to the contents of the repository by simply cloning, although your changes will not be added as suggestions on the original repository without forking.

answers.text: So that you can have the repo locally
answers.comments: Cloning alone will give you the contents of the repository for you to work with, there is no need to fork unless you wish to collaborate with the original repository owner.

answers.text: I don't know
answers.comments: Be sure to review the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time!

answers.text: A command that creates a separate set of commits from other commits to the same repository.
A command that creates a copy of the repository in your git profile
A command that combines two repositories.

A command that switches your work to the main branch.

questions.question_text: What is the command to check out and begin working on an existing branch called bobs_branch?

answers.text: git switch bobs_branch
git branch bobs_branch
git new bobs_branch
I don't know

questions.neutral_comments_html:

answers.text: branch
Branch

answers.text: A request to other members of a team that two branches be merged.
